answers.answer: Hi - It sounds like you have a lot on your plate!Can I assume the the doc you mention is your Primary Care Physician? If so I would go see a neurologist, rather than relying on your PCP to relay information. Before I was diagnosed I saw my PCP, mid major relapse. She didn't think it was MS, but rather dehydration :-) Thankfully she also told me I needed to see a neurologist.We need to be our own healthcare advocates. Don't just accept things your PCP tells you. Your symptoms seem pretty specific to me; facial pain, tinnitus, burning sensations...What diagnostics has she used?I would go see a neurologist :-)Kyle

Hi Kyle,Thank you for your reply. Im in the UK, my doctor is my GP - General Practitioner, when I first went with symptoms she passed it off as saying her guess was it will go as quickly as it came and also said it was probably dehyration and told me to drink soda water as i could have a salt inbalance.  Oddly also the pains started when i was already on Lyrica/Pregabalin which they prescribed for burning arm pain/neuralgia which seems to have ceased over 4 months, but they advised me to keep taking the lyrica for General anxiety as they thought thats what could have been causing my burning arm.  i accept i have been through alot health wise, but I really dont think my burning arm or even these facial zaps are due to anxiety.   She asked me to go back if it continued.  I have done and she really has no specific answers, she said if I was suffering from MS id get weakness of the limbs down one side, all I have had is burning arm which has now gone.  i had this for about 5 months after i had recovered from heart failure.  I now have these facial zaps and burning scalp, the facial shocks/zaps i have been having every day for a month, they last seconds.  But because I am not rolling along the floor in agonsising pain, she said its not Trigeminal neuralgia and Trigeminal Neuralgia is almost always on one side, rarely bilateral, mine is bilateral but not at the same time.  She said she will write to the neurologist and explain my symtoms and he can decide if its worth seeing me!  This could take ages.Today I have enquired privately about paying for a consultation to see a Neurologist, but I will still need a referral from my doctor.I know googling symtoms is the worse thing, but all it points to is Trigeminal Neuralgia, which concerns me because I am only 36 and it says likely to be Brain Tumour or MS causing the TN. But I dont have any weak limbs/muscles.  So due to the tinnitus, electric shocks, i also have stiff neck that cracks and sounds like gristle, a few headaches I am thinking its a Brain tumour, I also noticed my Jaw seems displaced and cracks or pops when I eat. This has only happened recently.  I have heavy proteinuria,  very stiff joints sore spine bones, and tested for all autoimmune, all negative. So i dont really know what all my symptoms point to and doctors seem to put it down to anxiety, apart from the protein in my urine which they are referring me to a kidney specialist for.Really appreciate your response, I will source a consultation with a neurologist.Best WishesYvonne

Hi Yvonne and welcome to our community.  I hope we can help some by walking by your side on your journey to find out what is going on in your body.  Many here would warn you (from their personal experience) that diagnosis can be a long, rough road - especially since you live in the UK.  (Nothing personal, it just seems the decision makers there drag their feet or have little desire to run expensive testing to diagnosis a life-long disease with expensive treatment options.)Multiple Sclerosis - if fact, most inflammatory autoimmune diseases - can be extremely difficult to diagnosis.  Some people with specific symptoms, MRI findings or spinal fluid analysis results have an easier time.  But even those folks often end up looking back and realizing they actually had symptoms years before being diagnosed.I haven't had a lot of trouble with TN but others here have.  Although most have had symptoms on one side only, a few expanded to bilateral presentations with time.  I think I remember reading somewhere on our forum that bilateral TN is unusual.... except in PwMS (people with MS).  BUT, I believe the initial symptoms of TN on the second side would be expected to appear a significant period of time following the first.There are two trigeminal nerves - left and right (oddly enough!).  They are a matched pair of cranial nerves of twelve sets that carry signals conveying important sensory and/or motor information.  The trigeminals branch into smaller segments only after they move away from the body’s midline.   To have similar symptoms appear on both sides simultaneously (even if not identically) would require a strategically placed MS brain lesion.Now, how long after your pregnancy did all this start?Pregnancy has a tendency to make the immune system a little less sensitive (so your system doesn’t over-react and harm that only half-familiar baby inside).  When a pregnancy ends a woman’s immune system begins to ramp back to full strength.  It’s a vulnerable time for ANY of the autoimmune diseases to show up full(er) force.Most of the additional symptoms you have added don’t sound much like MS - and certainly not brain tumorish.  They could be associated with lots of other rheumatic type inflammatory autoimmune diseases though - and it does NOT matter that initial testing was negative!  As I started before.... these types of problems can be extremely difficult to diagnosis.  Many have no SPECIFIC diagnostic test (even if some docs claim they do).Hopefully some of our other UK members will be along to help you navigate the health system.  I wish I had a better idea about who would help you more - a neurologist versus a rheumatologist.I do hope you are able to enjoy more of the blessing of your life and your child’s soon.Mary

Since your doc is having trouble figuring out what you have, you might ask to be tested for Borreliosis.  The European presentation is usually different from North American Lyme, and is usually more concentrated in the nervous system.  Lyme especially likes certain cranial nerves, connective tissue, and joint fluid. As a result, it mimics many neurological and immunological disorders.Ask your doc for a Western Blot, as the screening test is quite unreliable, especially in patients with primarily neuro symptoms.You might find www.lymeneteurope.org helpful.  Most doctors all over the world are sadly unaware of Borrelia and coinfections (other tick borne diseases) that can make it worse.

Mary & Ricobord,Thank you very much for your replies, for logical and constructive feedback Mary.My baba is10 months old, Mary i know you are right about the what pregnancy does to your immune system, before my pregnancy I had a positive ANA titre of 1;160 Necleolar pattern raynalds and telangesticas on my lips (sp), possible scleroderma, i was tested again while pregnant and my ANA was negative (obviously because my immune system was supressed) i developed pre-eclampsia and then 3 days after birth went into congestive heart failure (Postpartum cardiomyopathy) and severe pulmonary edema, trying not to sound dramatic i nearly died and woke up in intensive care, and very grateful to be here with my baba (she had her own problems!) they dont know the cause of PPCM (1/15000 births) but think its autoimmune when the mothers immune system kicks back in, some antibodies kick off and tackle the heart.  Some mothers pass, some mothers stay in heart failure but on meds for the rest of their lives, and some mothers like myself heal quickly and recover full heart function.  So i am so very lucky.  They dont know why some mothers heal and others dont but it is to do with the immune system but how they are not sureI continued to have high levels of protein in my urine after pregnancy, and still do now 10 months later, which isnt normal, which is why they did the whole auto immune panel tests again, all of which are negative still.  You are also right about the UK dragging their heels with diagnosis for chronic illness's, but at the same time the NHS system saved my daughters life that cost thousands, plus my own in an acute situation, without the worry of insurance.  So it does work sometimes! ;)I have also had a word with myself about if it was a brain tumour would i really have TN start on boths sides although not at the same time (literally the same day!) and yes it would have to be strategically placed, but my mind goes further and illogically plays out scenarios of it could be placed on the left causing compression, but growing and pushing on arteries to the right, causing compression on the right hand side too.  Again I know this is totally irrational thoughts, but i guess with everything that has happened I am a sucker for rarity.  Maybe i should play the lottery )Maybe just the nerves in my face are irratated, but i sure wish it would go away, its getting more frequent each day, and affecting my ears deep inside too.  Doc has checked and no infection.  My scalp burns for periods at a time and the electric shocks have been deliberating tonight.Thank you so much for your support, Its really appreciated.Yvonne

Hi again Yvonne.  Your answer has triggered several more thoughts but I'm pressed for time at the moment.  Here are a few basic points until later.Have you been tested for B12 deficiency?  Or tried a sub-lingual supplement even if testing showed 'normal range'?  B12 deficiency causes neuro symptoms and is easily treatable unless you wait too long and the damage becomes permanent.  Blood loss, drugs that decrease stomach acid, diet changes and loss of appetite are things that could spark B12 level decline.  Maybe not the whole answer.  Could contribute.Has anyone considered Celiac disease or gluten intolerance without Celiac?  Celiac can cause neuro symptoms even with few or no digestive symptoms.  PwMS sometimes report great improvement when they eliminate gluten from their diet.  (If you are going to be tested for it, do NOT reduce gluten containing products until testing is complete.  Diet change beforehand can invalidate results.)Things like this might be of great value to help you feel better regardless of other diagnostic outcomes.All health care systems have flaws galore.  Ask any citizen, any country.  I'm sorry I forgot to acknowledge how well your national system worked during your delivery/post-partum/neonatal difficulties.  I remember thinking it must have been a comfort to know you both received the care you needed without additional worry over mounting bills.  Despite my long answer, it's one of the things I forgot to actually say.Please remind me here or by private message if I fail to get back to you.  Sometimes I lose track of time and promises (as well as answers).  Sad.  But true.Mary

Mary thanks so much for you reply.Yes i have been tested for Vitamin B12, is was in the normal range.  I am just slightly aneamic, due to iron, so i am taking iron tablets, i also take B12 anyway.  I have been vegetarian, for 20 years, but my diet is terrible (i eat hardly anything or just carbs) and surprisingly my blood were all okay, the only thing that hasnt been tested is vitatmin, which my GP said is worth doing .i have had terrible electical pain in my left eye today, and right jaw and cheek, so oppossite side, also in my scalp just above my hair line, its really getting to me, my neck also hurts,and my ears feel full of pressure like they need popping, i have tired and they dont need to pop! so i am convincing myself more and more is a tumour.  I have a tendency to just think the worse.  Very rarely i know TN doesnt start bilaterly esp in my age (36) and thats why i think something sinister is going on.  No one has considered Celiac disease, i will have a look at that on line.There were a few blunders when my baby was born they could have prevented what i had going so far, but because it was so rare, it wasnt picked up on, and the put initial symptoms down to the preeclampsia, then a blood clot on my lung, and it just escalated from there.  however my daughter was treated at one of the best childrens hospital in Europe, we were lucky to live close by to it.  She had the best care we could have hoped for.

Hi, Just throwing ideas around, so feel free to ignore :o)These jaw issues didn't by any chance start after having an opp? The reason for the question is that when i had my tonsils out when i was 29, I woke with my jaw screaming 10+ pain, bilateral pain but the left side was the killer shot.I already had an iffy jaw, dentist discovered a couple of yrs prior that my jaw was twisted out of the left socket, so i thought the opp had put it out again but the surgen said the ?? (sorry lost the word again) was probably irretated and it would eventually settle down, a dentist told my mum the same thing last week. I suspect that its a common enough problem for either and it 'usually' does settle, how much time it takes may depend on an individual. hmmm thinking of dental, wisdom teeth can rumble and cause this type of bilateral pain too.The other thing is about mental health, apart from suspecting health anxiety is what your doc is thinking, have you ever had your mental health assessed? If you haven't since the birth and medical issues, then i highly recommend you do, even if its just to discredit that idea, and if you do need some help in that area, then thats got to be a good thing, right?Anyhoo, just thinking out loud so as i said, feel free to ignore :o)Cheers..........JJ

question: Hello everyone, Ive not been diagnosed with MS and also not having much luck with my doctors.  I've been experiencing what I think is bilateral trigeminal neuralgia &  burning left arm for months (which has now ceased), my doctor doesn't think it's trigeminal neuralgia because it's bilateral and rare! But the pains are electric shocks lasting seconds (pain being a 6 out of 10) and follow the path of the trigeminal nerves, I get them both sides of my face but not at the same time. I get burning scalp sensations lasting minutes or hours. I also get pain in my ears both sides deep inside, constant tinnitus but this can only be heard in a quiet room when I go to bed, and sounds like its in my actual head not ears if thAt doesnt sound odd! Ive occasionally had numbness and tingling in my legs but only once or twice. I've been worried its a brain tumour, or MS. My doc has said all she can do is write to the neurologist and ask what he thinks and whether he wants to see me or not, as my symptoms are too vague. Also I think they think it's all anxiety related as I've been through a lot this last year health wise, mainly heart failure caused by pregnancy and my daughter being born with diaghramatic hernia, we've both recovered and I'm very lucky and blessed. But I don't want them to put everything down to some health anxiety these symptoms are real to me and I'm scared I have a brain tumour, or maybe this could be early onset of MS?Does anyone have advice? Thank you for readingBest wishes
title: Advice
